description: Verb from Middle English scornen, schornen, alteration of Old French escharnir, from Vulgar Latin *escarnire, from Proto-Germanic *skarnjan, which could be from *skeraną (“to shear”) (from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker- (“to cut”)), or possibly related to *skarną (“dung, filth”) (from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ḱerd-, *(s)ḱer- (“dung, manure, filth”)). Noun from Old French escarn (cognate with Portuguese escárnio, Spanish escarnio and Italian scherno).

entries.meaning: (countable) A display of disdain; a slight.
examples: Every sullen frown and bitter scorn / But fanned the fuel that too fast did burn.

entries.meaning: (countable) An object of disdain, contempt, or derision.

verbs.description: Verb from Middle English scornen, schornen, alteration of Old French escharnir, from Vulgar Latin *escarnire, from Proto-Germanic *skarnjan, which could be from *skeraną (“to shear”) (from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker- (“to cut”)), or possibly related to *skarną (“dung, filth”) (from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ḱerd-, *(s)ḱer- (“dung, manure, filth”)). Noun from Old French escarn (cognate with Portuguese escárnio, Spanish escarnio and Italian scherno).
scorn (third-person singular simple present scorns, present participle scorning, simple past and past participle scorned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To feel or display contempt or disdain for something or somebody; to despise.
examples: We scorn what is in itself contemptible or disgraceful.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To refuse to do something, as beneath oneself.
